Andy, the biggest difficult here will be the CPU time this kind of 
experim=
ent may require.  In effect it takes the square of the time 
it would take =
to simply run evolution in a domain with a regular 
parameter set. That is =
because e.g. if you had populations of size 
100, then it you'd need a meta=
-population of 100, each of which is 
an evolution of population 100.

Perh=
aps however on some small problems this would still be 
feasible.  (Certain=
ly with parallel processing it also becomes more 
feasible)  Yet it's impor=
tant to remember that it is likely that 
what you are finding are the right=
 parameters for *that* problem, 
rather than the best ones in general (it's=
 likely there is no 
such "best"). 

In any case, if you did run such an ex=
periment, it's a good question 
what the inputs would be.  I would add to y=
our list inputs that let 
the network see the current parameter settings, e=
.g. the current 
mutation rate, etc.  That way, it can deduce, e.g., "hey t=
he slope 
isn't good and I have a really low mutation rate so maybe I shoul=
d 
notch it up a little."  That is, it's useful to know what state 
you're =
in before you think about changing it.

With that in mind, you might consid=
er the outputs being delta values 
rather than absolutes.  In other words, =
they would request 
a "normalized" change magnitude on their respective par=
ameters.  
That way the network has (in an abstract sense) an "egocentric" =

perspective of how it moves through parameter space.  However, if 
that do=
esn't work well, you can always try absolutes (on a 
normalized range).  In=
 either case, I'm imagining one output for 
each evolution parameter that t=
he network controls.

Good luck,

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "afcarl=
2" <a.carl@...> wrote:

>    I am currently working on a version of neat t=
o supervise neat, 
by 
> way of manipulation of the parameters on a generat=
ion by 
generation 
> basis for the purpose of attempting to accelerate the=
 integral of 
the 
> fitness of the underlying neat task (UNT). The byprodu=
ct would be 
the 
> evolution of a supervisor genome.
>

oughts regarding inputs to the supervisor are as 
> follows:
> 
> 1) normal=
ized log of UNT generation #,
> 2) last UNT generation highest fitness (HF)=
,
> 3) last UNT generation HF accum,
> 4) # of generations since last chang=
e of HF of UNT,
> 5) average of UNT generation HF,
> 6) slope of average of=
 UNT generation HF (last 2 points),
> 7) slope of HF accum (last 2 points).=

> 
>    Does anyone have any thoughts regarding the contemplated 
inputs, =

> and/or suggestions for possible other candidate inputs?
> 
>    Thoughtf=
ul suggestions are always appreciated!
